processed_nodes.label: To-do list
processed_nodes.problem_description: This appears to be a specific personal document but is labeled generically, creating ambiguity and potential collisions with other to-do lists or the class concept. No temporal data is required for an Entity. Overall classification looks correct; main issue is naming specificity and discoverability.
processed_nodes.resolution_notes: 1) Rename for disambiguation using an owner-qualified pattern, e.g., "Jukka's To-Do List" or "To-Do List (Jukka)"; ensure consistent hyphenation per naming standard. 2) Add aliases: ["Jukka's todo list", "Jukka task list", "Personal to-do list (Jukka)", "todo list"]. 3) Add structural edges: has_owner/maintained_by -> Person:Jukka; instance_of -> Concept: To-do list (if concept/class exists; if not, create it); is_a -> Document (or your graphâ€™s document superclass). 4) Improve connectivity as applicable: maintained_in/tool -> (e.g., Notion/Obsidian) if known; about/topics -> Task management, Personal productivity. 5) Add privacy/visibility metadata (e.g., visibility: private/internal; sensitivity: personal). 6) Optionally refine description to note it is a living personal task tracker maintained by Jukka and, if known, its platform or inception year. 7) Ensure a unique slug/ID that includes the owner (e.g., to-do-list-jukka) and align capitalization with labeling policy. 8) If a class-level "To-do list" node exists, ensure no label collision and link via instance_of; if it does not exist, avoid using the bare generic label for this instance.
